fields.description:
We get a lot of support cases, where customers upgrade JIRA (the war edition generally) from a previous version and are seeing bugs due to JSPs being cached from the previous version in Tomcat's work directory.

We should add a note to our upgrade docs that if customers are upgrading JIRA and installing the WAR edition in the same application server they should delete Tomcat's work directory to avoid stale JSPs from being cached.
fields.summary: Add a note about deleting the work directory when upgrading the war distribution from a previous installation of JIRA

fields.description:
When using the 'source' applink, it concatinates any lines after it unless there is a space (or some other terminator I imagine) after it.  In other words:

source:trunk/project/blah.cpp
source:trunk/project/blah.h

On my JIRA with applinks installed tries to link to a file in fisheye called trunk/project/blah.cpp\nsource:trunk/project/blah.h instead of creating two distinct applinks.

If I put a space at the end of each line above, it creates two separate applinks like it should.
fields.summary: JIRA source: applink to FishEye requires space 'terminator'

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-20133].
  {panel}

We have clients who likes to have filter that will allow them to bring up the list of issues that they have commented on. We also think this is useful. Currently, there is no way to filter on updated by field since field is not available on the interface. It would also be nice to incorporate the time factor in to designing this feature. 
For example, I would like to see all the incidents that I have commented on (reporter and assignee could be someone else) since last 15 days.

I hope this explains what is needed.

Thanks. 
Pontis Product Development
Michael Baker Jr., Inc.
fields.summary: A way to filter the issues based on which user has commented.

fields.description:
It would be a very useful feature, especially given the inability to have multiple issue navigators open at the same time, if from the Tools menu on the Issue Navigator page if there was an option to open all of the displayed issues in new tabs or windows.

This should just be a little bit of Javascript and adding a class or something to the issue links.  It would save lots of time when we're in a review meeting and will be going through all of the issues in a navigator - especially because sometimes the changes we make in the meeting make the issue no longer match the criteria for that issue navigator.
fields.summary: Option to open all issues in an issue navigator in new windows/tabs

fields.description:
I suggest a new plugin, JIRA integration for Openproj (Serena). It's a free, open source tool, that came to replace Microsoft Project's "hegemony". We start to use JIRA and Openproj some time ago, and we believe that this integration can add a plus to JIRA's feature, since Openproj is open source. When searching google and several forums, I found little information about this integration.


Thanks for your support!
fields.summary: Integration with OpenProj (Serena)

fields.description: It would be nice to have a feature (that can be turned on or off) that would automatically adjust issue keys to expand to a particular length - or the length of your max issue number.  For example: you have JRA-1, but when the 10th issue is entered (JRA-10), JRA-1 would become JRA-01.  Even if this was only done for exporting to excel it would be useful for sorting in Excel.

The issue is referenced in this case (https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-48470)
fields.summary: Clicking the preview button multiple times in comments deletes the data in comment

fields.description:
Searching for a URL such as "http://redmine.nscontext.eu/issues/show/2899" in an issue's comment (as well as other fields probably) is broken in JIRA 4.0.  In JIRA 3.13 searching for the URL above would have yielded results.

This seems to be caused by the Lucene upgrade in JIRA 4.0.

There's a difference in the queries being produced:
JIRA 4.0
+body:"http redmine.nscontext.eu issu show/2899"

JIRA 3.13
+(body:http body:"redmine.nscontext.eu issu show/2899")
fields.summary: Searching for URL in comments is broken

fields.summary: Email notifications sent in different recipient's locale

fields.description:
■ Present Behavior

On the issue details page, in the "All" tab (for example), entries are associated with timestamps that appear as English phrases:

Chip added a comment - 2009-08-27 09:54 AM
Dale made changes - 2010-01-12 07:24 PM

In Japanese, they appear as:

Chip がコメント - 2009-08-27 09:54 午前 を追加
Dale が - 2010-01-12 07:24 午後 を変更

The grammar of these Japanese-language phrases is incorrect.


■ Desired Behavior

The correct grammar is:

Chip がコメント - 2009-08-27 09:54 午前 に追加
Dale が - 2010-01-12 07:24 午後 に変更

and, within this context, the fully-intelligible and therefore recommended form is:

Chip がコメント - 2009-08-27 09:54 午前 に追加しました
Dale が - 2010-01-12 07:24 午後 に変更しました

** The desired change is the "を" → "に", and adding "しました" to the end of the phrase.


■ Steps to reproduce

0. Sign in to JIRA, ensure the user's locale is set to Japanese.
1. View an issue whose "All" history presents items that have undergone both "Added" and "Edited" operations.
2. Observe the present behavior


よろしくお願いします。
fields.summary: Japanese localization: Grammar of issue history timestamps

2) Set the Due Date to "14/Jan/65536" and save the issue.
3) Search for the issue in the Issue Navigator.

A velocity error is displayed instead of the search results:

{noformat}

fields.description:
Currently when you use the time tracking functionality in Jira, it assumes a 24 hour day.

In my experience when working on development/support projects, when we talk in terms of "days" we mean days effort (often measured as 7.5 hours to one "day"), not calendar days.

It would be nice if there was an option to have different time tracking configurations (like is provided for other things just as field configurations).  The idea being is that you could define a time configuration that specified how many hours there are in a day.  Then, JIRA's time tracking calculations could take that into account.  This would help as when an estimate of 5d is entered, the person usually means 5 7.5-hour days, not 5 24-hour days.
fields.summary: Time tracking - ability to define working hours

It does not signify *users* in the error message as does the English translation.

*Correct:*
_English (United States):_
"A group or user with this name already exists."

_German (Switzerland)_
- "Eine Gruppe oder ein Benutzer mit diesem Namen ist bereits vorhanden"
- becomes: "A group or a user with that name already exists"


*Incorrect:*

fields.description:
The email template velocity variables $constantsManager and $projectManager point to com.atlassian.jira.config.ConstantsManager and  com.atlassian.jira.project.ProjectManager, both of which have a substantial number of methods that are deprecated in v4.0 and there's no way to access the new methods indended to replace them. This means, for example, that there's no way to get the components for a project. 

The Release Note template is so out of date it doesn't match your basic meta data. Tasks and Subtasks are both included outside of the issue types they're tied to. The release notes template doesn't even have the velocity variables available in the email templates. Customizing the template is virtually impossible in any meaningful way unless you have access to the source code for the ReleaseNoteManager class. In particular, there's no way to iterate over issues by issue type and then by component or vice versa. There's no way to create a set, rather than a list, so that components can be sorted per issue type. Basically, the template is unusable out of the box and impossible to customize without access to the source code.

By not allowing an automated way to produce release notes, you are literally costing your customers thousands of manhours a year. Each release requires someone to extract the relevant data and reformat it. Consider the frustration of using a software product that requires you to cut and paste fields and reformat for every release, rather than simply allowing you to export the information in a reasonable way.
The reason you don't get many votes for release note issues is because the individuals likely to have accounts with JIRA are mostly developers and not technical writers. Despite that, there is a clear trail of individuals trying to figure out how to do this over a number of years in your development forums - and failing. This seems like a feature that would take a minimum of time to fix, and be very appreciated by the customers.
fields.summary: JIRA Templates Out of Date

For example, notice that the first comment on this issue is blank from when I sent example.txt to this issue via an email.

Steps:
1. Login to JIRA and create a permission scheme.
2. Set browse project permission as "Current Assignee"
3. Please refer to permission screenshot for other permissions.
4. Associate the permission scheme to a issue and create a issue and sub task.
5. Login user can assign issues.
6. Assign the sub task to some other user.

Result:
1. User gets a big error message "It seems that you have tried to perform an operation which you are not permitted to perform." though the issue is currently assigned to the other user.
2. It seems that after assigning the user when JIRA try to show the issue, its unable to do due to permission and give this error message which is misleading.
3. Giving browse permission to all users solve the issue but its important as "Current Assignee" is an option in permission list.

Expected:
1. No error message and scenario should be handled gracefully.

fields.description:
I want to be able to number the Issues according to their type

Option 1
Have a special letter for each issue type: 
- for bugs: {Project Key)-B-0000, i.e. TST-B-1234 
- for Requirements: {Project Key}-R-0000, i.e. TST-R-1234
- for Test cases: {Project Key}-T-0000, i.e. TST-T-1234

Option 2
Use the same numbering but each issue type starts in a different number
- bugs start at 0, i.e. TST-1234
- Requirements start at 50000, i.e. TST-50123, so all requirements are 5xxxx.
- Test cases start at 70000, ie. TST-70123, so all Test cases are 7xxxx.

I know that the issue type is for that and that each type of issue can have it's own icon, but I think have a scheme like this one makes it even easier.
fields.summary: Have a different Issue numbering scheme for each Issue Type

fields.description:
Picking a random item from a collection is used in many cases. 

For example, you want a random item from the collection photos that is filtered through a certain filter. Currently this can be accomplished by counting the resulting query, computing a random index within that count, and then getting that item with that random index. 

A easier approach would be requesting a random item directly from mongo given a query

photos.find({"author":"johndoe"}).random()  
// this would act like .next() but instead would simply return a random item that matches the query

photos.random_one({"author":"johndoe"})
// this would act just like find_one, except it would return a random item that matches the query
fields.summary: Random item from Collection

fields.description:
When you have customfields with utf-8 characters, for example Dérivés, then in the xml file that is created:

E.g. [http://localhost:8080/sr/jira.issueviews:searchrequest-xml/temp/SearchRequest.xml?query=Donner+AND+GP+&summary=true&tempMax=1000]

We see the following:

{code:xml}
               </customfield>
                                                <customfield id="customfield_10083" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:select">
                    <customfieldname>Périmètre</customfieldname>
                    <customfieldvalues>

                        <customfieldvalue><![CDATA[Dérivés]]></customfieldvalue>

                    </customfieldvalues>
{code}

The value is wrapped in CDATA and not encoded. 

This causes confluence jiraissues macro to throw 

{noformat}
java.io.IOException: Error on line 2433: Invalid byte 2 of 3-byte UTF-8 sequence.
        at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.jira.DefaultJiraIssuesManager.getChannelElement(DefaultJiraIssuesManager.java:163)
        at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.jira.DefaultJiraIssuesManager.retrieveXML(DefaultJiraIssuesManager.java:192)
        at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.jira.JiraIssuesServlet.getResultJson(JiraIssuesServlet.java:165)
        at com.atlassian.confluence.extra.jira.JiraIssuesServlet.doGet(JiraIssuesServlet.java:98)
        at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:690)
        at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:803)
        at com.atlassian.plugin.servlet.DelegatingPluginServlet.service(DelegatingPluginServlet.java:42)
        at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:803)
{noformat}

Also if you visit the url in IE, IE will throw an invalid xml error. 

If the characters are encoded as the other fields (description, summary etc), then the xml will render fine in IE and display in JiraIssues. 

The workaround if possible is to specify the encoded values for the custom field. I.e. rather than set "Dérivés" set 

{noformat}
Dérivés
{noformat}

and this will show up in the UI as "Dérivés" but will be passed as the encoded value when the xml is built.
fields.summary: select list customfieldvalues not being encoded when exported to xml, this causes the JIra issues macro to fail.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-20053].
  {panel}

Clarify the instructions on moving/removing the JavaMail JARs in the SMTP configuration:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+JIRA+to+Send+SMTP+Mail
http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/v3.13.5/smtpconfig.html

We should instruct people to check for the existence of the JARs in the app server and move/replace accordingly, rather than giving them specific instructions based on their specific app server.

Reason: Some operating systems, such as Red Hat Enterprise Linux, ship the JARS with Tomcat while most do not. So we cannot base the instructions on the specific app server.

_Info:_ I have already updated the instructions on CAC:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+JIRA+to+Send+SMTP+Mail

To be done: Update the instructions for JIRA 3.13 -- as requested by a customer:
http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/v3.13.5/smtpconfig.html
fields.summary: Clarify instructions on moving/removing JavaMail classes in SMTP config

fields.description:
I (and believe many others) have an extreme need to override some of the JIRAS default(built-in) components.

Currently we have an opportunity to do so using Plugin v1. framework.
My concerns are: this type of plugins will not be supported forever + I'm trying to switch to new Plugin Framework (which I believe is supported one).

Please describe what is the supported method for overriding component in JIRA 4.x (not using plugin framework v.1 components)?
I understand that is JIRA customization and might include some JIRA xml file editing and so on, but I really should know what the supported/recommended way is, to make my code maintenance and shift to next JIRA version easier and not so painful.

Please also update http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/PLUGINFRAMEWORK/Component+Plugin+Module wiki page to make developers life easier.

Thanks for advance.
fields.summary: Please update Plugin Framework v2. ComponentModule plugin type with information what is the v2. supported way to override default JIRA's component

Hello,
Due to our business model implemented in JIRA we do need to link some custom fields with Logging system in order to create various reports.

fields.description:
These three abilities:

# The ability to move issues out of a project
# The ability to move issues into a project
# The ability to create issues in a project

are currently covered in only two permission types:

# Move Issues (controls #1)
# Create Issues (controls #2 and #3)

The ability to move issues into a project (#2) should be handled by a separate permission type than the ability to create issues (#3).

As an example scenario where this is important, consider a company with a division that has a subdivision.  One JIRA project exists for the entire division, and a separate project exists for the subdivision.  A single group of individuals is responsible for monitoring the work of the entire division.  Members of the subdivision should be empowered to add issues to their own project without waiting for explicit assignment by the triagers, but not without the monitors of the entire division being notified of the existence of the issue at least once (at issue creation time).

The ideal solution here would be to set it up so that members of the subdivision must create issues in the division's project, thereby triggering notification to the monitors, and then the members of the subdivision could move their own issues into their own project, thereby reducing email traffic at the division level.  To do this, it is necessary to allow members of the subdivision to move issues from the division project into the subdivision project but not allow them to create issues in the subdivision project directly, since that would bypass notification of the monitoring group.  There is no way to do this because in order to grant the subdivision users permission to move issues into their project they must be given Create Issues permissions which will also allow them to create issues directly in the subdivision project, allowing them to bypass notification to the triage group.

The solution would be to have three permissions, "Create Issues", "Move Issues Into" and "Move Issues Out Of" in the Permission Schemes.
fields.summary: Permissions to move an issue into a project should be independent of the ability to create issues in a project

fields.description: When an issue is transitioned from "Resolved" to "Closed", the Resolution date field is reset to the date it was Closed.  Ideally, the Resolution date would reflect the date that an issue was first resolved, not the date that the code was released, or some other date that gets set in the Resolved date field due to some administrative action on the ticket.
fields.summary: Resolution Date should not be reset if an issue is transitioned from one resolved status to another resolved status

  {panel}

Many of my uers are requesting the ability to perform the following

Change Condition - a field changes from any value to any value (including ablity to specify values that change) - at any point in time - not just the latest change. This information is displayed in the change history.

Modified Date - between 7 and 0 days ago - basically to allow both a concept of "today() functionality and "today()" and a range of dates.

Change Author user or current user - change author at a given time - not the user to last update.

Record changed between 11/30/09 and 12/07/09 and authored by Smith, David W
and Status != Closed - again not the user to last update.

This is severely limiting research capabilities of our users as out legacy product had this ability.

fields.description:
The Text Gadget accepts a title and some HTML. The HTML is entered into a textarea field that is approximately 250 x 50px, which is very small.

The obvious workaround is to copy & paste from another editor but it seems buggy that this needs to be done for any non-trivial amount of data.

Another possible workaround is to use a browser that allows for the resizing of textarea fields (or, in the case of Firefox, using a plugin like https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/3818).
fields.summary: Text Gadget's textarea field is too small

fields.description:
Currently, if you are setting up your JIRA instance and upgrades are run, if an upgrade task throws an exception or adds an error, the screen the user is shown immediately afterwards is the "Setup has completed" screen. Once the user clicks any link, they are redirected to the errors screen where the error which occurred is actually displayed.

The user should be redirected to the error screen immediately so that there is less confusion.
fields.summary: If upgrade task returns error or throws exception, the user is still shown the "Setup has completed successfully" screen

fields.description:
Upgrade Tasks in JIRA are supposed to be idempotent - that is, if you have to run it multiple times (for whatever reason) then it should be able to execute each time and not screw up.

Currently, when an upgrade task adds an error as if to signal that the upgrade task did not complete successfully, it *still* creates the record in the UpgradeHistory table in the database. This means that in future, this task will be skipped because it is deemed to have already been run. This seems a bit counter-intuitive: if the task had an error, it would probably require re-running at some point after the error is corrected.
fields.summary: When an upgrade task adds fails and adds errors, it cannot be executed again

fields.description:
When creating a user with password normally, the notification email to that new user will contain the password.
However creating a new user and leave the password blank, JIRA randomly generates a password for that user, but the randomised password "is not sent" in the notification email to that user. Hence the user have to click the forgot password link in the login page for JIRA to generate a new password and sent that password to the user.
fields.summary: Randomised password not sent in email

Original report of the problem:
{panel}
When trying to export an arbitrarily large # of issues to Excel, We found that the excel export is truncated to 184KB.

If I select all fields, it will limit the # of rows as appropriate. If I select "Current Fields" it will export up to 184KB.

I have experienced this in:
Firefox 3.5.2 and 3.0.14
Chrome 3.0.195.27

This does not affect IE 7 (.0.5730.13).

Client OSes = Windows XP / Server 2003.

I have been informed that the same problem exists on Snow Leapord w/ FireFox 3.5.x
{panel}

Some more details...

If a _filter_ is used to view the issues, the problem _does not_ occur, but if it is an _issue search_, it does.

fields.description:
If I manually edit a specific issue to change the fix version of the issue I get an entry in the changegroup and changeitem tables reflecting the change.  If the same change is done via a bulk update, no update is written to this table.  This problem can also be seen in the change history UI.  There is no data reflecting the change.

The problem is that we need a way to construct the status of our project at points in time in the past (how many items were open against target X 2 weeks ago) which works great if we don't bulk change the fix version.  If we do bulk change the fix version, then the change history is out of sync with the current value.  Right now the query I thought would work is showing a ton of issues against a release we cancelled and bulk moved. 

We also lose the ability to determine who made the change.

I have not checked if this affects all fields, or just this one field, as this is the one causing a problem right now.
fields.summary: Bulk change of fix version does not place a change record in the change group/item table

fields.description:
I created a directory in the <jirahome>/installed-plugins and it turns up as a broken plugin

{code}
bbaker@carltondraught:~/src/atlassian/releases/jira4.0/jirahome/plugins/installed-plugins$ ls -l
total 1572
drwxr-xr-x 10 bbaker bbaker    4096 2009-12-21 10:34 as
{code}

and then

{code}
2009-12-21 10:37:16,171 main ERROR     [atlassian.plugin.loaders.DirectoryPluginLoader] Unable to deploy plugin 'null', file Unit: jirahome/plugins/installed-plugins/as (1261352060000)
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: The artifact URI file:/home/bbaker/src/atlassian/releases/jira4.0/jirahome/plugins/installed-plugins/as/ is not a valid plugin artifact
	at com.atlassian.plugin.DefaultPluginArtifactFactory.create(DefaultPluginArtifactFactory.java:38)

	at com.atlassian.plugin.loaders.ScanningPluginLoader.loadAllPlugins(ScanningPluginLoader.java:88)

	at com.atlassian.jira.plugin.JiraPluginManager.start(JiraPluginManager.java:49)

fields.description:
Problem Description:

*Steps to reproduce*
- Create an issue and attach a flash movie to it (see attachment)
- Embed the movie into the description using the following syntax
{code}
 !LoadingTasks.swf|width=669,height=267!
{code}
!LoadingTasks.swf|width=669,height=267!


*Observed*
- Under firefox using flash player 9 the movie is shown. For other browsers or flash player version 10 nothing is shown.

*Isolation*
- Looking at the source code that is generated by jira, we observed that the HTML is missing equal signs for assigning the parameter names:
Observed HTML
{code}
<object 
     classid="clsid:D27CDB6E-AE6D-11cf-96B8-444553540000" codebase="https://download.macromedia.com/pub/shockwave/cabs/flash/swflash.cab#version=6,0,0,0" data="/secure/attachment/10409/10409_innerLens.swf" type="application/x-shockwave-flash2-preview" >

<param name"data" value="/secure/attachment/10409/10409_innerLens.swf"/>
<param name"loop" value="false"/>
<param name"menu" value="false"/>
{code}
fields.summary: Non-standard HTML is generated when embedding flash movies

	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardWrapperValve.invoke(StandardWrapperValve.java:213)

	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardContextValve.invoke(StandardContextValve.java:172)

	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardHostValve.invoke(StandardHostValve.java:127)

	at org.apache.catalina.valves.ErrorReportValve.invoke(ErrorReportValve.java:117)

	at org.apache.catalina.core.StandardEngineValve.invoke(StandardEngineValve.java:108)

	at org.apache.catalina.valves.AccessLogValve.invoke(AccessLogValve.java:581)

	at org.apache.catalina.connector.CoyoteAdapter.service(CoyoteAdapter.java:174)

	at org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11Processor.process(Http11Processor.java:873)

	at org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11BaseProtocol$Http11ConnectionHandler.processConnection(Http11BaseProtocol.java:665)

	at org.apache.tomcat.util.net.PoolTcpEndpoint.processSocket(PoolTcpEndpoint.java:528)

	at org.apache.tomcat.util.net.LeaderFollowerWorkerThread.runIt(LeaderFollowerWorkerThread.java:81)

	at org.apache.tomcat.util.threads.ThreadPool$ControlRunnable.run(ThreadPool.java:689)

	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:619)

Caused by: javax.xml.bind.MarshalException

 - with linked exception:

[javax.xml.stream.XMLStreamException]

	at com.sun.xml.bind.v2.runtime.MarshallerImpl.write(MarshallerImpl.java:332)

	at com.sun.xml.bind.v2.runtime.MarshallerImpl.marshal(MarshallerImpl.java:172)

	at com.sun.jersey.json.impl.JSONMarshaller.marshal(JSONMarshaller.java:123)

	at com.sun.jersey.json.impl.provider.entity.JSONRootElementProvider.writeTo(JSONRootElementProvider.java:139)

	at com.sun.jersey.core.provider.jaxb.AbstractRootElementProvider.writeTo(AbstractRootElementProvider.java:143)

	... 103 more

Caused by: javax.xml.stream.XMLStreamException

	at com.sun.jersey.json.impl.writer.Stax2JacksonWriter.flush(Stax2JacksonWriter.java:334)

	at com.sun.xml.bind.v2.runtime.output.XMLStreamWriterOutput.endDocument(XMLStreamWriterOutput.java:107)

	at com.sun.xml.bind.v2.runtime.XMLSerializer.endDocument(XMLSerializer.java:854)

	at com.sun.xml.bind.v2.runtime.MarshallerImpl.postwrite(MarshallerImpl.java:379)

	at com.sun.xml.bind.v2.runtime.MarshallerImpl.write(MarshallerImpl.java:326)

	... 107 more
{code}

Its TOO much and makes supporting JIRA all that much harder, invokes panic in customers and supports alike and for good measure hides the actual cause of the problem.


So far in my time in support I have seen hundreds of these log messages (as expected) and it hinders problem resolution


We need to do something about this.  Just what is the trick.  JAXB/Jersey is doing the logging calls and wrapping exceptions.  However maybe we can do something at the log4j level to tweak how these messages get formatted and printed.


See

https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/REST-108

and kinda related

https://studio.atlassian.com/browse/REST-107
fields.summary: JAXB log messages are too much.. for an IOException

fields.description:
The date picker allows you to choose a date like 2040 but by default this will be set as a date with a two digit year which causes it to be interpreted as 1940 as per the century selection algorithm for two digit years in Java's SimpleDateFormat.

Problem Description:

Client Due Date: 31-Dec-1940
Expected Completion Date: 16-Dec-1932

Both were set to 20XX not 19XX

This is related to a Java date bug. 

From Atlassian support from ticket JSP-49395:
Weird, but I also came across that this is in the design. Java just assumes that if you are using 2 digits for the date it falls somewhere between 80 years before and 20 years after the date it was created.
{Quote}
For parsing with the abbreviated year pattern ("y" or "yy"), SimpleDateFormat must interpret the abbreviated year relative to some century. It does this by adjusting dates to be within 80 years before and 20 years after the time the SimpleDateFormat instance is created. For example, using a pattern of "MM/dd/yy" and a SimpleDateFormat instance created on Jan 1, 1997, the string "01/11/12" would be interpreted as Jan 11, 2012 while the string "05/04/64" would be interpreted as May 4, 1964.
{Quote}


http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/text/SimpleDateFormat.html
fields.summary: Default date format is two-digit and loses century chosen in calendar picker

fields.description:
We still testing JIRA. Our enterprise bought a JIRA license for 25 users, but we want to manage special issues witch need to associate external payable development support for resolving our Software bugs or to acquire material i.e. spares to fix some problems. In this case special user must be created to authorize or decline the treatment of issues depending on the amount of money it's involve.
As we are beginners in the world of JIRA it is possible that we don't see this feature in our JIRA Evaluation product.
fields.summary: Adding authorization from particular users in special issues witch need to acquire materials or external support
